title: Why Your Skin Looks Dull â€” & What Will Actually Help, According To A Derm
text:
Why Your Skin Looks Dull â€” & What Will Actually Help, According To A Derm

One thing that comes with the territory of being a beauty director is that friends, family, and colleagues always tap me for skincare advice â€” over text, email, or even in the office bathroom. Unlike a dermatologist or esthetician,Â Iâ€™mÂ not a qualified expert, though I like to thinkÂ Iâ€™veÂ got a little knowledge under my belt. But one skin dilemmaÂ thatâ€™sÂ stumping even me is why everyone thinks their skin looks so dull right now.Â 

Maybe itâ€™sÂ colder weather, central heating, or a lingering post-holiday skin hangover. Whatever the cause, dullness is a skin concern most of us are dealing with â€” so I asked a top dermatologist to break downÂ whatâ€™sÂ behind it and whatÂ actually helps. Without further ado,Â hereâ€™sÂ how to make dull skin radiant in a fewÂ easy steps, many of which you can do with products youÂ likely alreadyÂ have at home.Â 

What does dull skin look like?Â 

Dermatologist Dr. OpheliaÂ VeraitchÂ says that â€œdull skinâ€Â isnâ€™tÂ a medical or dermatologic diagnosis: â€œItâ€™s a descriptive term used to explain skin that lacks clarity, even tone, and light reflection,â€ she explains. When the skinâ€™s surface becomes uneven, sheÂ adds,Â it prevents light from reflecting properly, making the complexion appear flat or tired.Â 

What causes dull skin?Â 

I hate to break it to you, but there could beÂ a long listÂ of factors behind dull-looking skin. The first â€” and most obvious â€” is a buildup of dead skin cells, says Dr.Â Veraitch.Â Your skin naturally sheds dead skin cells as newer ones take their place, but some skin types might need a little help clearing them. More on that later.Â Â 

Another underlying cause of dull skin is dehydration, says Dr.Â Veraitch. While drinking water throughout the day supports overall health and skin,Â topical hydrationÂ through lotions and serums is also important for combating dullness.Â 

Environmental stressors are another factor. Pollution particles, Dr.Â VeraitchÂ explains, can cling to dead skin cells, oil, and sweat, leaving behind an uneven, lackluster surface.Â 

Whatâ€™sÂ more, skin inflammation â€” from conditions like acne, psoriasis, or rosacea â€” as well as hormonal skin changes such as melasma, and a compromised skin barrier (like dry or eczema-prone skin) can all contribute to dullness.Â 

How can you get rid of dull skin andÂ make it brighter?Â 

Dr.Â VeraitchÂ suggestsÂ itâ€™sÂ important not to self-diagnose: â€œThe most effective way to treat dull skin is to identify and manage any underlying cause,â€ she says. â€œThis is why I always recommend seeing a dermatologist first â€” particularly if dullness is driven by inflammation, pigmentation, or a chronic skin condition.â€Â Â 

Perhaps you only experience occasional breakouts andÂ donâ€™tÂ haveÂ a chronicÂ skin condition. If so, Dr.Â VeraitchÂ says you canÂ simplyÂ adjust your at-home skincareÂ routineÂ â€”Â and keeping it consistent playsÂ an important roleÂ in improving skin brightness.Â 

What are the best skincare products for dull skin?Â 

First up: exfoliation â€” specifically, the chemical kind. Alpha hydroxy acids (AHAs) are especially effective at lifting dull, dead skin cells and revealing healthy new ones. Glycolic acid isÂ arguably theÂ most popular recommendation among skin experts for its ability to brighten the skin, minimize the appearance of hyperpigmentation, and smooth rough texture over time. A leave-on toner or serum applied at night is your bestÂ option.Â 

A favorite of mine isÂ The Ordinary Glycolic Acid 7% Exfoliating and Brightening Daily Toner, whichÂ containsÂ 7% glycolic acid. After cleansing, I pour a little onto a cotton pad and swipe it over my entire face and neck each evening, then follow with a simple, hydrating moisturizer.Â 

Seven perÂ centÂ glycolic acid isÂ relatively high, so ifÂ youâ€™reÂ new to AHAs,Â go a little lower.Â Beauty editors wax lyrical aboutÂ TatchaÂ TheÂ Texture Tonic AHA Liquid Exfoliating TreatmentÂ with exfoliating glycolic acid andÂ soothing JapaneseÂ mugwort, andÂ Beauty of JoseonÂ Refreshing Toner, with glycolic acid and moisturizing glycerin.Â Â 

If your skin is on the sensitive side, consider lactic acid. Its molecules are larger than those in glycolic acid, which means itÂ absorbs intoÂ the skin more slowly and gently â€” making it a better choice for reactive skin types. TryÂ Olay Super Serum Night Repair 5-in-1 Face Serum, which combines lactic acid with skin-strengthening peptides, orÂ The Ordinary Lactic Acid 10% + HA 2%, whichÂ containsÂ 5% lactic acid and hyaluronic acid for added hydration.Â 

Exfoliating acids make skin sensitive to sunlight, so be sure to wear a high-factor, broad-spectrum sunscreen during the daytime.Â Â 

Is retinol good for dull skin?Â 

Retinoids like retinol, retinal, and prescription-strength tretinoin also help improve skin brightness. IfÂ youâ€™reÂ a beginner, the same rulesÂ apply:Â go low and slow. TryÂ TheÂ InkeyÂ Listâ€™s new Starter Retinol SerumÂ orÂ The OrdinaryÂ GranactiveÂ Retinoid 2% Emulsion. BothÂ containÂ granactiveÂ retinoids, which are formulated to release slowly and gently into the skin, helping reduce irritation.Â 

IfÂ youâ€™reÂ a pro, Dr.Â VeraitchÂ recommends herÂ Night SerumÂ with tretinoin, whichÂ increasesÂ cell turnover andÂ improvesÂ overall skin clarity.Â Â 

You can use retinol and exfoliating acids in the same routine, but it pays to be smart. The number one rule?Â Donâ€™tÂ layer them, which can leave your skin sore, sensitive, and dry.Â Itâ€™sÂ better to use glycolic acid at night after cleansing, then introduce retinol a couple of nights later, always following with moisturizer and applying sunscreen in the morning.Â 

Are antioxidants good for dull skin?Â 

OnceÂ youâ€™veÂ got your evening skincare figured out, Dr.Â VeraitchÂ suggests adding one more ingredient to your morning routine: an antioxidant. There are plenty to choose from, including vitamin C, resveratrol, vitamin E, ferulic acid, and niacinamide. Each works a little differently, but at their core, they all help protect skin from environmental aggressors â€” like smoke and UV â€” that can make it appear dull.Â 

Arguably, theÂ most popular antioxidant is vitamin C, which acts like a force field around the skin while brightening in the process. Dr.Â VeraitchÂ often recommendsÂ SkinCeuticalsÂ C E FerulicÂ to her patients to protect against oxidative stress and boost radiance. ItÂ containsÂ a trifecta of antioxidants: vitamin C, E, and ferulic acid. IfÂ youâ€™dÂ prefer to spend less, tryÂ e.l.f. Bright Icon Vitamin C + E + Ferulic Serum. For even better results, apply your antioxidant serum before sunscreen to maximize protection against UV rays.Â 

Which facials are good for dull skin?Â 

Lastly, if you have a bigger budget, Dr.Â VeraitchÂ suggests a medical-grade treatment, which she says can significantly accelerate results. She likes to combine theÂ HydraFacial PlatinumÂ â€” a non-invasive facial that removes dead skin cells â€” with extractions. â€œI follow this with Clear + Brilliant, a low-energy laser that gently but effectively brightens the skin, refines texture, and evens out skin tone.â€ Even better,Â thereâ€™sÂ no downtime.Â

title: 5 Expert Tips That Helped Me Grow Longer, Stronger Nails, Fast
text:
5 Expert Tips That Helped Me Grow Longer, Stronger Nails, Fast

Growing out my nails has never been my strong suit. Until recently, I could barely make it a few weeks before breaking one while doing something as untaxing as zipping up my jeans, let alone facing every nailâ€™s nemesis: the ring pull on a can of Coke.Â 

To give them a fighting chance, Iâ€™d take skin, hair, and nail supplements like they were going out of fashion, wear gloves while carrying out even the smallest of chores, and refrain from using my nails as tools to open my mail (we all do it). Frustratingly, none of those things worked. What I needed was some expert guidance.Â 

Over the past year, Iâ€™ve collected tips and tricks from nail technicians, dermatologists, and even TikTokâ€™s manicure obsessives. But I wonâ€™t gatekeep. These are the six simple, and most importantly, affordable pieces of advice I was given for longer, stronger nails that actually worked.Â Â 

I chose cuticle oil over nail hardeners

Dr. Dana Stern, board-certified dermatologist and founder of Dr. Dana, says that the cuticle is the nailâ€™s natural protective seal. When it becomes dry and dehydrated, itâ€™s compromised: â€œWhen this happens, water and moisture can enter the nail unit,â€ she says. â€œThis causes all sorts of problems, including redness and swelling,â€ and eventually, the nail could grow irregularly: â€œThink white patches, bumps, thickening, and discoloration,â€ she says.Â 

While most nail technicians will trim or remove dead cuticle skin during a manicure for aesthetic reasons, using cuticle oil still offers multiple benefits for the remaining skin surrounding your nails, as Iâ€™ve discovered: â€œRegular application of cuticle oil helps maintain hydration,â€ says consultant dermatologist Dr. Zainab Laftah. â€œHydration benefits both the nail and surrounding skin by reducing brittleness, enhancing nail health, supporting healthy nail growth, and preventing infections,â€ she adds.Â 

Unlike nail hardeners, which can make nails a little too hard, session manicurist Ami Streets says that cuticle oil keeps nails flexible, withstanding everyday wear and tear. â€œCuticle oil is the best product for growing nails â€” and my most recommended item to add to your beauty routine,â€ she says.Â 

Dr. Dana recommends her Nourishing Cuticle Oil, with jojoba oil and indigo naturalis, a Chinese plant known to repair and strengthen the skin barrier. Complete with a handy roller ball for easy, drip-free application, itâ€™s an oil I can vouch for, having used it down to the very last drop. Another of my favorites is Sally Hansen Vitamin E Nail & Cuticle Oil, with moisturizing vitamin E and a dream team of nourishing plant oils. Streets also loves Lâ€™Occitane Shea Nail & Cuticle Oil, which is twice as moisturizing as the impressive hand cream in the same collection, and Jessica Phenomenoil, another oil weâ€™ve both used up.Â Â Â Â 

Besides ingredients, exactly how you use your cuticle oil matters, too. Streets says that a single drop on each cuticle is ample â€” and itâ€™s best applied at night to give the oil time to absorb. Not only does cuticle oil hydrate deeper than hand creams, but Streets and Dr. Dana say that the massaging motion could help stimulate circulation and promote nail growth, too. Â 

I switched from traditional gel to builder gel â€” or BIAB

Not all gel nail polish is created equal. On my brittle nails, most would chip quickly. Iâ€™d then pick off the polish and damage my nails even further. It wasnâ€™t until a fellow beauty journalist recommended Builder in a Bottle â€” also known as BIAB or builder gel â€” that my nails grew long and strong. Iâ€™m almost a year in, and I havenâ€™t had a single chip or break. Theyâ€™re growing so quickly that I always ask my nail technician to cut them down.Â 

â€œBuilder in a Bottle is a specific type of gel that lends strength and structure to natural nails,â€ explains Streets. Thanks to its stronger base, Streets says that itâ€™s a great option for those who want to reinforce their nails while trying to grow them, as they can last up to three weeks. Another great thing about BIAB is that it can be infilled, says Streets. This involves getting the grown-out gap near your cuticles filled in with more gel, rather than having to fully remove the polish each time. â€œThis allows natural nails to maintain growth,â€ adds Streets, but she recommends a maximum of two to three repeated infills before having a short break to keep your nails healthy and happy.

Thanks to BIABâ€™s harder, more durable finish, Dr. Dana says that it not only serves as a â€œprotective armorâ€ for nails, but it typically has a forgiving, less damaging removal process by soaking off, so it tends to be more advantageous than other nail enhancements like acrylics. â€œIâ€™ve seen patients who use BIAB and have very healthy nails in comparison to my patients who wear acrylics and do constant soak-off gels,â€ she says, adding that BIABâ€™s durable nature also makes it a good option for nail biters.Â 

I addressed my vitamin D deficiency

When a blood test revealed that my vitamin D levels were low, I began taking a 2000 IU vitamin D supplement daily alongside my trusty omega-3, 6, and 9. While there are multiple health benefits to both, Dr. Laftah points out that they could have additional advantages for nails: â€œAddressing a vitamin D deficiency can improve nail health as low levels can result in brittle nails,â€ she tells me. Interestingly, one small study suggests that hapalonychia â€” a condition that causes nails to become soft and prone to breakage â€” has been associated with vitamin D deficiency.Â As for omega-3? â€œIncorporating omega-3 fatty acids into your diet may also benefit nails by providing essential nutrients that support overall nail strength and integrity,â€ Dr. Laftah says.

However, Dr. Dana points out that no robust studies prove that vitamins or supplements benefit nail health. But since nails are made of keratin (a type of protein), she suggests that if your diet lacks sufficient protein, it may be worth considering protein supplementation to improve the condition of your nails. Streets also advises incorporating more protein into your diet and drives home the importance of staying hydrated.Â 

Before adding supplements to your routine, consult your doctor to ensure theyâ€™re safe and suitable for you.

I took hand cream very seriously

Previously, Iâ€™d only use lotion when my hands were uncomfortably dry and on the verge of cracking. Over the past few months, though, Iâ€™ve taken moisturizing very seriously, and Iâ€™m convinced that keeping my hands adequately hydrated throughout the day has also benefited my nails.Â 

I was right. For clients who want longer, stronger nails, Dr. Laftah recommends moisturizing regularly to maintain hydration. â€œUsing a nourishing and hydrating hand cream can help,â€ adds Streets. â€œNot only does it keep skin in a supple and soft condition, but it can also act as a protective barrier against environmental stressors,â€ â€” like cold weather. Streets says that dry, cracked skin and cuticles can lead to infection or weak nail growth, so consistent daily use of a moisturizing product is essential.Â 

If you want fast hydration without the sticky feel, I love Aveeno Daily Moisturizing Hand Cream. If your hands are especially dry, my all-time favorite hand lotion is Lâ€™Occitane Shea Butter Hand Cream. The silky soft feeling sticks around for hours â€” even post-hand-wash. â€œOn application, make sure you use a massaging motion,â€ advises Streets. â€œIt can help to boost blood flow to hands and cuticles, which supports new nail growth even further.â€

I started using a glass nail file

Dr. Dana believes that many nail files, particularly traditional, rough emery boards, can be too abrasive for natural nails, potentially causing â€œmicroscopic tearsâ€ that lead to splits and breakage. Thatâ€™s where glass or crystal nail files come in. On days when I gave my nails a break from BIAB, Iâ€™d file away rough edges with a glass file, which Iâ€™m certain is kinder on nails.Â 

â€œIn contrast [to emery boards], glass creates a perfectly smooth, split-free edge to the nail,â€ says Dr. Dana, who uses the Precision Glass File. Likewise, Streets believes that a glass nail file is a worthwhile investment for at-home manicures: â€œThey provide a finer and more controlled filing experience, and the smooth edges help seal the keratin layers at the nailâ€™s edge, preventing splitting, peeling, and snagging that can occur when using a rougher emery board.â€ Whatâ€™s more, Streets points out that glass nail files are non-porous and can be washed or sanitized between uses.

Lastly, I exfoliated my nails

With its ability to exfoliate the skin, leaving it smoother and brighter, glycolic acid is a staple in many skincare routines, but it can benefit your natural nails, too. In between BIAB appointments, Iâ€™ve often applied a glycolic acid toner to my nails and cuticles using a cotton swab, then followed with a glug of cuticle oil. The result? Fewer flakes and a stronger, smoother canvas for nail polish. If youâ€™d rather not DIY, try the Dr. Dana Nail Renewal System, a once-weekly, 3-step nail system that boasts glycolic acid, a nail primer, and a hydrating gel-oil to reveal healthy, hydrated, and shiny nails, fast. â€œItâ€™s perfect for brittle, peeling, weak nails, post-gel damage, or if you simply want a gorgeous, healthy-looking shine without having to go to the salon,â€ says Dr. Dana.

title: I Thought Hair Growth Products Were A Scam â€” Until I Discovered These
text:
I Thought Hair Growth Products Were A Scam â€” Until I Discovered These

As a beauty director, itâ€™s hard not to be a skeptic. With dermatologists on speed dial and cosmetic chemists just an Instagram DM away, I can bust dubious skincare myths (sorry, you canâ€™t put collagen back into your skin), and get their opinion on ingredients (hyaluronic acid isnâ€™t all itâ€™s cracked up to be). But having such a wealth of information at my fingertips means that Iâ€™ve become very particular about which products earn a spot on my bathroom shelf.Â 

Iâ€™m not sold on neck cream, nor am I a huge fan of hair gummies, and until recently, there wasnâ€™t any room for hair growth serums, shampoos, or conditioners in my routine. Honestly, I thought they were futile. Hereâ€™s the thing: Having spoken to a handful of trichologists over the years, I know that hair growth is mostly down to genetics. When it comes to hair growth shampoos, especially, they tend to sit on the scalp for a short amount of time, and whether they actually do anything has long been disputed by experts. That said, itâ€™s been hard to ignore the buzz around one hair growth brand lately.Â 

Enter: Typebea, the invention of singer-songwriter Rita Ora and Anna Lahey, also the founder of supplement brand Vida Glow.

When Typebea launched in April of 2024, it took many of my beauty editor peers by surprise. A handful extolled the virtues of the Strength + Length Conditioner, $26, which had made their hair feel â€œlike silkâ€, while others loved that the Overnight Boosting Peptide Serum, $52, gave them three times as much volume. Unconvinced, however, I put my samples aside. It wasnâ€™t until Iâ€™d booked in for a salon blowout, where I happened to have my hair washed and professionally styled using the brandâ€™s products, that I sat up and took note. It was probably the best my lengths had looked (voluminous and shiny) â€” and felt â€” (thick and strong) in a long time. I incorporated the shampoo, conditioner, and serum into my haircare routine that weekend.Â 

After a month or so of using all three products, I started to get compliments on how long and healthy my hair appeared: â€œAre you wearing extensions?â€ and â€œDidnâ€™t you have a bob a few moments ago?â€ are just a couple of common questions Iâ€™ve fielded of late. A couple of months since I started using Typebea â€” and now on my second bottle of shampoo â€” my friends canâ€™t quite believe how quickly my hair is growing. Even my hairdresser, who listened to me moan about how my lengths took forever to reach my shoulders, is stunned by the abundance of new baby hairs that have suddenly sprouted along my hairline.Â 

Besides taking more care of my hair (not going to bed with it wet, investing in a microfibre towel), using the shampoo, conditioner, and serum consistently is the only significant change to my routine. It got me thinking: Have I got hair growth products all wrong? And what is it about Typebea that seems to work so well?

What are the ingredients inside Typebea hair growth products?

Without subjecting you to a science lesson, both the G1 Overnight Boosting Peptide Hair Serum, $52, and Strength and Length Shampoo, $26, feature the ingredients baicapil, salicylic acid, and provitamin B5. The brand claims that they promote hair growth, exfoliate the scalp, and keep it moisturized respectively. The Strength and Length Conditioner, $26, also boasts baicapil and provitamin B5, with the addition of plant-based keratin, said to smooth frizz, repair damage, and enhance shine. Intrigued â€” and still a little bit doubtful â€” I asked independent trichologists for their thoughts on the ingredients inside everything. Mainly, I wanted to know whether I really did have some genuinely game-changing hair growth products on my hands.Â 

What is baicapil â€” and is it good for hair growth?

Eva Proudman, consultant trichologist FIT IAT, previously told R29 that baicapil is a plant-based ingredient derived from scutellaria baicalensis, a Chinese herb. â€œ[This herb] has antioxidant properties that can support hair health,â€ said Proudman. â€œIt is normally combined with other botanicals such as soy, which hydrates the hair and scalp, and can improve hair texture by smoothing the cuticle,â€ essentially making lengths appear shinier. Proudman pointed out that wheat sprouts are also used in the products. â€œWheat sprouts can help to improve texture by reducing the effects of free radicals [think UV and pollution] and provide hydration and a smoothing [effect] for the hair fibre.â€Â Â

One of the most useful things Iâ€™ve learned from trichologists is that healthy, stronger hair is largely dependent on the condition of the scalp, which is why itâ€™s recommended to wash it as regularly as you can manage. What is provitamin B5 â€” and is it good for hair growth?

title: â€œI Didnâ€™t Want Him In My Life:â€ The Pain & Peace Of Familial Estrangement
text:
â€œI Didnâ€™t Want Him In My Life:â€ The Pain & Peace Of Familial Estrangement

It was the first time in 12 years that Gaby had spoken to her father. It didnâ€™t go well. Her sister had persuaded her to hear him out after years of trying. Okay, thought Gaby â€” so long as she didnâ€™t have to promise a certain outcome. Sitting across from her dad, she felt her heart sink when he said he â€œdidnâ€™t want to drag stuff back up,â€ as he put it. The thing is, she did want to discuss things from the past. It was important to her, if they were to become civil at the end of this, though that outcome was looking increasingly unlikely with each minute that passed.Â 

â€œHe denied multiple events, lied, denied knowledge of my mental health issues and told me it seemed like there was nothing he could do to change my mind about our relationship, so why should he bother,â€ remembers Gaby, who is 25 and didnâ€™t want to share her last name. He didnâ€™t apologize for anything and spoke about his own upbringing in a way that Gaby felt was designed to â€œguilt tripâ€ her into having a relationship with him. â€œI had the conversation as a favor to my sister. I will not be doing that again. He seems to have worked on himself over the years from what my sister says, but not in regards to his relationship with me.â€ Gaby feels that further efforts to reconcile would be futile.Â 

Estrangement is so painful because good familial relationships are automatically expected. In the years that Liam and Noel Gallagher, the famously feuding brothers of Britpop band Oasis, were in bitter separation, both brothers were asked repeatedly in interviews if theyâ€™d work things out. In a similar vein, this week, Brooklyn Peltz Beckham also addressed his own familial situation by making a statement on Instagram saying he â€œdidnâ€™t want to reconcileâ€ with his family, the Beckhams. Thereâ€™s something about troubled family relationships that we canâ€™t let rest in the way we do when other relationships break down. Confronting it is painful. The Gallaghers are a unique case, though. Their recent reunion in summer â€™24 was made to look easy and their former conflicts a source of entertainment. They also probably had a big motivator: money. Regular estranged or tense family relationships donâ€™t get that material and emotional support. In the US, there are a few (though not many) organizations supporting estranged families, including Together Estranged and PEAK. The UKâ€™s leading charity in helping estranged people cope, Stand Alone, ceased operations in April this year due to financial struggle, and nothing has yet taken its place.Â 

Even if someone dealing with estrangement has contact with other family members, those family members often arenâ€™t equipped or neutral enough to know how to help. Sometimes, involvement from others makes the whole thing one messy hotpot of guilt-tripping, arguments, resentment and a heat that will burn the tongue. Twenty-nine-year-old Ebony, who doesnâ€™t want to share her real name, is estranged from her cousins, who she grew up with and viewed as her brother and sister. They cut her off last year after a wider family feud involving their parents and grandparents. â€œI get pressured by other family members all the time both directly and indirectly to reconcile,â€ she says. â€œThere are multiple family members who have tried talking to my cousins, encouraging them to reach out to me. This upsets me, because no one should be going and asking someone to reconcile with someone else. If that person has to be forced, then itâ€™s not worth it. Iâ€™m trying my hardest to not let it affect my relationship with my other cousins who I am also close with. But unfortunately it does affect it and it does make things awkward.â€ The situation has damaged Ebonyâ€™s mental health; before the point of no contact, she felt used as a metaphorical â€œpunching bagâ€ by her estranged cousins when the relationship became turbulent. Even if reconciliation were an option, it wouldnâ€™t be easy, and sheâ€™d have to confront the verbal abuse she was subject to.Â 

Financially, people who are disconnected from their families lack a support system many of us take for granted. While not every family has the means to help out, even if the will is there, lots of us do have the luxury of being able to return home for a period when life gets hard â€” when romantic relationships end, for example, or we lose our jobs. Therapist Eimear Oâ€™Mahony says: â€œMany people who experience estrangement do not have the financial, physical, emotional support of family. This can mean there is a higher rate of financial worry and struggle in comparison to others who have family to help with kids or who know they will have inheritance in the future.â€Â 

Therapy can help with the guilt that often comes from cutting contact with family. Writer Fern Schumer Chapman, who was estranged from her brother for over 40 years, wrote in her book Brothers, Sisters, Strangers that when siblings cut ties, theyâ€™re left in â€œa world of secrecy and shame,â€ even if theyâ€™ve made the right decision for themselves. The feelings that come with this decision are complex and will vary by person depending on why theyâ€™ve chosen to cut ties. Liz Kelly, therapist and author of This Book Is Cheaper Than Therapy, says: â€œIt is very common for people who cut ties with family members to experience guilt. They may have received societal, cultural or religious messages to put family over everything. Itâ€™s challenging to make a different choice when facing that pressure.â€Â 

People are complicated and some still care about family theyâ€™ve cut out of their lives. â€œItâ€™s possible to love a family member and need to set limits due to their behavior,â€ Kelly explains. â€œFor example, you might love your father, who is addicted to alcohol, and make a decision not to visit him to protect yourself and your children from his violent behavior. These decisions are complicated. Most people who cut ties with a family member typically do so after much thought, deliberation and previous attempts to continue and repair the relationship.â€ Oâ€™Mahony adds that estrangement can feel similar to grieving at times, because â€œit often doesnâ€™t feel natural to the human mind to accept that we choose to not see, for example, a parent.â€

Gaby feels lucky that her mom respects her decision to remain estranged from her dad but she can sense that her mom hopes they will have a relationship one day. Even that must feel like a weight to carry. â€œOver the years there were a few attempts within the family to â€˜fixâ€™ things, including family counseling. But each time he would say or do something that reaffirmed that I didnâ€™t like him as a person, didnâ€™t think he was a good dad and didnâ€™t want him in my life,â€ Gaby says.Â 

Some people are better off not reconciling, even with the emotional and financial strife it may cause. Oâ€™Mahony says it boils down to whether rebuilding the relationship would be â€œharmful or detrimental to the physical, emotional or psychological health of an individual.â€ These cases often involve trauma, abuse, neglect and harm, she explains. â€œMany people who decide to cut contact will go through waves of wondering, Am I doing the right thing? so the decision to not reconcile is only one part of a very complex process. It is so important to have support, understanding and non-judgement.â€ Lots of Oâ€™Mahonyâ€™s clients experience stigma surrounding this subject â€” friends donâ€™t know what to say when it is brought up, or when questions like â€œWho are you spending Christmas with?â€ are asked. â€œThe judgement, confusion and lack of understanding from others can be very harmful.â€ Oâ€™Mahony recommends therapy for those who can access or afford it. As Gaby puts it regarding her own situation: â€œAs time has gone on, I have only experienced more reasons to keep him out of my life.â€ The best thing we can do is let estranged people live in peace with their choices.
